selective.intro:
Aluminium and oxygen react to produce aluminium oxide.
4 Al + 3 O2 → 2 Al2O3
selective.question: How many kilograms of aluminium oxide are formed when 5.4 kg of aluminium react with excess oxygen?
selective.explanation:
The correct answer is: 10.2 kg. Every 4 moles of aluminium make 2 moles of aluminium oxide. The relative atomic mass of aluminium is 27 g mol<sup>-1</sup>. The relative molecular mass of aluminium oxide is 102 g mol<sup>-1</sup>. 
The mass of aluminium oxide produced is: 5400 g × (102 g mol<sup>-1</sup> ÷ 27 g mol<sup>-1</sup>) × (2 ÷ 4) = 10200 g.

selective.intro:
Calcium carbide and water react to produce ethyne and calcium hydroxide.
CaC2 + 2 H2O → C2H2 + Ca(OH)2
The volume of one mole of any gas is 24 dm3 at room temperature and pressure (r.t.p.).
selective.question: What is the volume of C<sub>2</sub>H<sub>2</sub> produced, at standard temperature and pressure, when 45 g of water reacts completely with calcium carbide?
selective.explanation: The correct answer is: 30 dm<sup>3</sup>. The relative molecular mass of H<sub>2</sub>O is: 18 g mol<sup>-1</sup>. The number of moles of water is: 45 g ÷ 18 g mol<sup>-1</sup> = 2.5 mol. The number of moles of ethyne is: 2.5 mol × (1 ÷ 2) = 1.25 mol. The volume of gas produced is: 1.25 mol × 24 dm<sup>3</sup> mol<sup>-1</sup> = 30 dm<sup>3</sup>
